Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Postdoctoral Research Fellowship award to Dr. Stephanie Alexandra Stuart is supported by both the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Office of International Science and Engineering at the National Science Foundation. During the 24-month fellowship, Dr. Stuart will work on a project titled, "Why be woody? Costs and benefits of stem construction" under the sponsorship of Dr. Steven Jansen at Ulm University in Germany, and Dr. Mark Westoby and Dr. Linda Beaumont at Macquarie University in Australia.

The goal of this project is to understand how plants grow tall and strong. Plants exhibit a variety of stem sizes and morphology, and this research will examine why plants have this diversity. This project will explore the costs of growing tall and strengthening stems, and how plants balance these costs against the energy they need for other functions such as reproduction. The research will provide answers to: 1) What do plants get out of building a stronger stem, and why are multiple strategies successful? 2) How do variations in stem design contribute to stem strength per unit investment? 3) How do changes in climate interact with costs of stem construction, leading to grassland to forest transitions? A species distribution model will be used as a theoretical framework for the study.

The PI will develop materials for a graduate workshop based on this research. The materials will be presented in the institutions in Germany and Australia, and eventually the US. Drs. Stuart and Jansen will develop a handbook on identifying functional traits at the anatomical level, which will be shared in Promethius wiki. Citizens will also be invited to join the project through a phenology trail on the Macquarie Campus. By visiting this trail, participants will have the opportunity to track the changing seasons by observing blossoming, new leaves, and ripening fruit in different plants.

This award provides a unique opportunity for a US scientist to collaborate with foreign scientists, and utilize the unique facilities, expertise and experimental conditions available abroad.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What did the project do? Data was collected in the German Alps. I looked at closely related pairs of plants, growing together in the same place. In each pair, one of the plants was taller, and the other was shorter. This means that the plants share a common evolutionary history, so most things about them are the same – the main difference was in how tall they grew. Some of these paired plants are shown in the pictures, for instance, the alpine willow, which grows to only three and a half inches tall, and its close relative the sapling willow, which grows to about 13 inches. Also shown are the beautiful magenta flowers of the fringed Rhododendron (~8 inches) and the rusty Rhododendron (~18 inches). I collected data on how fast plants have grown in the past five years, how tall they are, how much is devoted to each part of the stem, how difficult it is to bend or break the stem, and how much herbivore damage has occurred.

 

What does the data show? The taller plants invested more in building stronger stems. This may have allowed the smaller plants to put more of their energy towards reproduction.

 

How does this help people? First, it gives us information that we can use to plan for the future. More carbon dioxide is being added to the atmosphere every year. Plants turn carbon dioxide in the atmosphere into carbohydrates, which they can use to build their stems. Our data shows that taller plants need more carbon to build their stems. As carbon dioxide becomes easier to acquire, we may see the growth of more taller plants, and fewer shorter ones. Knowing this helps farmers, foresters, and land managers know what kind of plants will grow best, and whether they need to take special actions to encourage smaller plants or discourage taller ones. This project also supported an undergraduate student in her first experience with ecological research and forged international links with labs in Australia, France, and Germany. It has helped me to further my postdoctoral training, which puts me in a better position to continue contributing new knowledge to the scientific community and the public in the future. In addition to my scientific outputs, one of my most important results during the project was the birth of my son. I especially appreciated the National Science Foundation’s supportive accommodations for new parents. One of the pictures shows him joining me for some fieldwork on a misty day in the German Alps.
